I think that the more generalized goal, combined with the more 
complex env=
ironment where everything can happen, can yield results 
the more similar t=
o natural evolution. 
In picbreeder the goal is one of this kind. "Be beaut=
iful, or just 
look like something". The environment is very complex also -=
 it is 
the human mind viewing a 2D picture. 

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com,=
 "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@...> wrote:
>
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "=
petar_chervenski" <petar_chervenski@> 
> wrote:
> >
> > If there is not a g=
oal in natural evolution (direct or not), any 
> > possible form of life wo=
uld have survived..
> >
> 
> This discussion is exposing an interesting phi=
losophical question 
> about whether natural evolution has any real goal.
>=
 
> I guess you could say the goal is to reproduce, but if you say 
that, 
=
> then I want to define TBE as "evolution where reproduction is based 
on 
=
> performance on a prior-defined goal other than reproduction 
itself."  
>=
 That is, if you make reproduction itself a "target," then the term 
TBE 
>=
 becomes meaningless.  
> 
> (Perhaps one could argue that it indeed is mea=
ningless anyway, but 
I 
> think it can be a useful term because I believe =
it makes a useful 
> distinction between some types of evolution and others=
 for the 
> purposes of discussion.)
> 
> ken
>
